greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Numerator of n/(n+15).
comment: Multiplicative and also a strong divisibility sequence: gcd(a(n),a(m)) = a(gcd(n,m)) for n, m >= 1. - _Peter Bala_, Feb 24 2019
link: Nathaniel Johnston, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
formula: Dirichlet g.f.: zeta(s-1)*(1-4/5^s-2/3^s+8/15^s). - _R. J. Mathar_, Apr 18 2011
a(n) = gcd((n-2)*(n-1)*n*(n+1)*(n+2)/15, n) for n>=1. - _Lechoslaw Ratajczak_, Feb 19 2017
a(n) = n/gcd(n,15), a quasi-polynomial in n since gcd(n,15) is a purely periodic sequence of period 15.

O.g.f. for reciprocals: Sum_{n >= 1} x^n/a(n) = Sum_{d divides 15} (phi(d)/d) * log(1/(1 - x^d)) = log(1/(1 - x)) + (2/3)*log(1/(1 - x^3)) + (4/5)*log(1/(1 - x^5)) + (8/15)*log(1/(1 - x^15)), where phi(n) denotes the Euler totient function A000010. (End)
mathematica: f[n_]:=Numerator[n/(n+15)]; Array[f,100,0] (* _Vladimir Joseph Stephan Orlovsky_, Feb 17 2011*)
program: (Sage) [lcm(n,15)/15 for n in range(0, 79)] # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Jun 09 2009
xref: Cf. Other sequences given by the formula numerator(n/(n + k)): A026741 (k = 2), A051176 (k = 3), A060819 (k = 4), A060791 (k = 5), A060789 (k = 6), A106608 thru A106612 (k = 7 thru 11), A051724 (k = 12), A106614 thru A106621 (k = 13 thru 20).
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 15 2005
